  • Paper 3, Section II, K

    Applied Probability
    Part II, 2012

    We consider a system of two queues in tandem, as follows. Customers arrive in the first queue at rate λ\lambdaλ. Each arriving customer is immediately served by one of infinitely many servers at rate μ1\mu_{1}μ1​. Immediately after service, customers join a single-server second queue which operates on a first-come, first-served basis, and has a service rate μ2\mu_{2}μ2​. After service in this second queue, each customer returns to the first queue with probability 0<1−p<10<1-p<10<1−p<1, and otherwise leaves the system forever. A schematic representation is given below:

    (a) Let MtM_{t}Mt​ and NtN_{t}Nt​ denote the number of customers at time ttt in queues number 1 and 2 respectively, including those currently in service at time ttt. Give the transition rates of the Markov chain (Mt,Nt)t⩾0\left(M_{t}, N_{t}\right)_{t \geqslant 0}(Mt​,Nt​)t⩾0​.

    Stochastic Financial Models
    Part II, 2012

    In a one-period market, there are nnn risky assets whose returns at time 1 are given by a column vector R=(R1,…,Rn)′R=\left(R^{1}, \ldots, R^{n}\right)^{\prime}R=(R1,…,Rn)′. The return vector RRR has a multivariate Gaussian distribution with expectation μ\muμ and non-singular covariance matrix VVV. In addition, there is a bank account giving interest r>0r>0r>0, so that one unit of cash invested at time 0 in the bank account will be worth Rf=1+rR_{f}=1+rRf​=1+r units of cash at time 1 .

    An agent with the initial wealth www invests x=(x1,…,xn)′x=\left(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}\right)^{\prime}x=(x1​,…,xn​)′ in risky assets and keeps the remainder x0=w−x⋅1x_{0}=w-x \cdot \mathbf{1}x0​=w−x⋅1 in the bank account. The return on the agent's portfolio is
